You can tell how big of a challenge re-entry is by his comments on it. Sometimes it’s assumed that technological advancement means every little thing we use on a daily basis has been replaced by something better. In the 60+ years of manned space flight we still haven’t found a better solution than brittle and highly inflexible ceramic tiles (of varying sizes). So I get his apprehension about it. I don’t think any re-entry is regarded as a routine thing. A material that can reliably do a hot or cold condition only probably easy, but one that performs every time in a wide range? The list shrinks fast.

Very true discussion of the problems with bureaucratic design-by-committee approaches.  You can't figure out everything sitting at a desk, and even worse in conference rooms where the least knowledgeable are allowed to make the decisions, then revisions become politically impossible.  Vibrations in the balloon structure on re-entry might be a main concern, and if that might pop off tiles.  The walls are relatively thin and flexible and rely upon internal pressure to keep the vessel rigid.  Starships have failed under just the weight of propellant when internal pressure wasn't maintained.  The original Atlas vehicle in the mid 1960's used a similar stainless-steel balloon structure and also had failures, as does the current RL-10 propellant tanks.  For sure orbiting is much harder, requiring Mach 22 horizontal to Earth, but the Soviets did it on their first manned launch, while first U.S. launch later was just a short ballistic trajectory (like cannon ball). 📡🐇The slimming down of wiring paraphernalia on the Raptor 2 is astounding. The time investment link to the tile system and risk reduction is interesting (ie. Hinge of flaps). Having booster legs or a landing tower is also of intrigue. The quick disconnect arm (q.d.r) to launch the ring on the stand is also engaging. The "list over drag" technique and "s" turns for longitudinal adjustment is quite a concept. Axis control via fins is of immense interest too.

That is one amazing production facility. Cool to see so deeply into the overall design thought processes employed at SpaceX. As a former aerospace engineer, I can tell you he has a handle on several aspects that many of the people I worked for, did not.

I like his no nonsense approach to digging down into what really matters and what doesn't as they move forward. And the iterative design technique, used in the far past in my type of aerospace and very little any more, is an obvious intelligent path to success. Often now, if a fresh off the 'board' design fails once or twice, it's history. Stupid methodology, more oblivious than obvious.

"We'll surely be launching Starship from the Cape"

YEAH BABY, we'll be watching in person when that happens, like we have many many times before. I live about 50 miles inland from that Canaveral. We will almost certainly make a short trip to the Banana, or wherever, to see that one.

I saw a couple of Sat Vs from the Cape, and all of the others from Orlando as a kid. I also saw most all of the shuttle launches and a few returns (with the double boom, one time waking rather confused because of it). I unfortunately also remember walking out of my Statics class one day to a very strangely shaped contrail and my stomach sunk, then heard about it twenty times on my way back across Orlando to home. Not a good day.

I liked the "it will take off fast"
Yeah, maybe relative to other large man carrying rockets, but you want to see FAST, and QUICK...look up SPRINT missile, one of my old man's 'babies'. 0 - Mach10 in about five seconds. Glowing white hot from air friction scant seconds later. Obviously a human would not survive that ride, though, about 100gs for seconds. He said the first stage seemed more like a controlled explosion than a burn....1.5 seconds.

I could be totally misinterpreting things here, and it’s definitely possible that some of Tim’s questions were TOO simple (maybe, for some of his viewers who aren’t super familiar with this stuff) but it actually appears as though he brings up some legitimate points that really made Elon consider looking at certain things, or looking at certain things differently. I mean, how much different is that than a design meeting where department heads get together to try to work out some of the issues with each’s parts/systems fitting together and the solving of potential issues. It’s almost like Elon could get a ton of good engineering ideas by just talking with people that are passionate about this stuff, and not just people who went through schooling to do this stuff because it was a rapidly expanding field, or there was potential for job security or whatever other reasons individuals enter a field that they aren’t IN LOVE with. I’m sure he probably does pay attention to a lot of other people’s chatter, but I guess I was just marveling at the fact that it’s refreshing to have such a (fairly) open business that’s willing to take suggestions or look outside the box, or even make public their designs and technology, where other businesses (competitors, potentially) could take some of the market share. Granted, it’s basically the top-tier of engineering (it’s why the term “rocket scientist” is used the way it is), so it’s not like the average person can do much with the “trade secrets”, since you would need MASSIVE funding, but it’s still refreshing to see an innovator and businessman doing it for reasons other than just trying to get rich. The world would be a much better place if more business owners and executives had any agendas aside from wealth or temporary success. It seems like he’s looking to make advancements whose rewards won’t be fully realized until long after our time. I can’t see the future, so maybe he has some big flaw that undoes all the good he has done, but I doubt it, and I hope that’s not the case. There aren’t a lot of invincible role models in the world. Not LEGIT role models, anyway.

7:05 - For you who don't know, Elon is talking about the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster. On January 28th, 1986, were seven crew members were killed when the shuttle exploded just 73 seconds after launch. The explosion was caused by the failure of O-ring seals used in the joint that were not designed to handle the unusually cold conditions that existed at this launch. Engineers knew about it and gave warnings, but the people in charge still decided to launch, not wanting to risk any more delays.

Not trying to step on anyone's toes here but a little piece of advice about interview etiquette from somebody who's worked many years with talent both on set and in post production, is that even though you may be highly intelligent and informed about the subject matter at hand, remember that you're interviewing them so always show etiquette in having respect to the guest for their time, expertise, and the soon incredible financial boost to your channel. You don't wanna respond to them as if you're giving approval to what they're saying. You should be saying, "Ok", or "I see" or "I understand", or "interesting, blah blah blah you get the picture. Saying "Yep, Yep, yes, Yep, Yep,".... over and over feels more like you're pushing a narrative suggesting that you agree with what Elons stating. meaning, "you already have this knowledge". OK, then why are you interviewing him?
(Record needle scratches) 
That's the dynamic I'm trying to highlight. Even if you know absolutely everything and every detail down to the last bolt about that ship, even if you think you know just as much as that talent that you're interviewing, you still are not Elon Musk and honestly the audience doesn't care about you showing us how smart you are. Most importantly it just gets a little annoying and interruptive. A director would say you're upstaging the talent.

I think this openness is one of SpaceX's great strengths. They share their problems and failures openly and this allows more people to try to contemplate the problems, contribute ideas. They should actually set up a website where they post their technical issues and problems and the general public can comment, offer ideas. For example...

All those problems with the heat shield tiles, Elon almost had the idea when he said "Don't they look like dragon scales?" Would designing heat a heat shield where the tiles were shaped and arranged like fish scales make the heat shield better? Fish scales are rigid and attached at one point, yet they accommodate all the bending and changes in the fish's body without ever creating a gap in the scales. The scales attachment at one point, shape and they way they are overlapped allows the scales to slide over one another with changes in shape. Its seems like this biological solution to a similar problem could make the heat shield on Starship better, more reliable, easier to manufacture and install. Fish scales also produce some hydrodynamic properties skin alone does not. Some kind of roller bearing effect in the boundary layer. I also think one shape of scale/tile could cover the fuselage and the nose cone using the same overlapping pattern with adjusted attachment point geometry. A slightly different scale may also solve the problem of protecting the joints on the aerodynamic flaps. A system of tiles that slid over top one another to some degree could provide the needed protection and range of motion. The flat sides of the scales could be machined or shaped such that the total thickness of tile at any point on the hull would be more or less the same. Thick sections were just one tile covers the area and thinner sections on the same tile where it overlapped or went under another tile. Maybe smooth changes in thickness could be designed in these transitions from one thick tile area to 2 or 3 overlapping areas.

Just thinking about what this guy has done ... he has the entire German car industry on their toes finally also being forced to go electric, with the world following ... his cars are outperforming the most powerful loud monstrous vehicles while silently passing them by ... the electronic in his car is also his own chip design, making his cars also the smartest and most progressive mass produced in the world ... he also realizes the fact that with the current battery technology there are significant hurdles to be taken in order to make electric cars truly environmentally friendly and he is working on that as well ... he is helping NASA and others out to get their satellites into orbit and astronauts up and down to the space station!!!, he has been able to run his own unique truly worldwide internet service that is another first and will bring education to very remote places, he is working on his hyperloop project that will revolutionize interconnecting big cities within minutes instead of many hours. I almost forgot, he is also the only person who parked a convertible in space 😂.
I don't expect him to be perfect in all parts of life, since despite of all his groundbreaking achievements he is human, but he also seems to be a humorous and good-hearted person overall as well, who also puts priority on the time with his children.

A missed opportunity to talk about why the Space Shuttle was essentially an ineffective success was because as a government funded system (i.e. Congress), it was required to have many different companies be involved in various parts of its construction, so the politicians can brag about the money they brought to those companies in their states. That added time, complexity, and risk, because every piece was made independently, and if they didn't seamlessly work together, that's when failures happen. Seperate companies also have their own quality and testing standards, but they don't test how their parts work with others.

It was mentioned the almost allergic reaction to changing something because of the added risk/reward wasn't good enough to justify doing it. It doesn't help the Space Shuttle was the most complex machine ever built in human history.

SpaceX is different because everything is built in-house, by one company. From the materials acquired to manufacturing and assembly, it's all under one umbrella. Quality control is total, and independent of interference from outside sources. The goal of every segment of SpaceX is the same. More efficient, more open to change and the ability to fix things is much easier.

Not saying government projects aren't a good idea, but SpaceX succeeds because they pretty much don't answer to anyone.

46:52 I don't know if the head of heat shields is going to reply in this video, but my guess is that they're using the horizontal lines — the breaks in the pattern — to compensate for the changing number of required tiles over the curve.

Why are there so many small heat tiles instead of just a few large ceramic pieces, or multiple large overlapping pieces for redundancy in case one cracks? I mean wouldn't having 1000 tiles add 1000 more points of possible failure?

Re: Grid fins for pitch trim vs body drag at 58:00, I think the main use of the grid fins for F9 or Superheavy is to steer the vehicle to the landing site, NOT to create more aero drag. The engine(s) decelerate it nicely, but the glide must be steered to the correct point long before the landing burn starts.

Imagine it like a skydiver exiting the plane at 25k feet and having to hit a net to land safely. Steering is important, not aero drag.

Back in 1988 I proposed deleting the landing gear from the Hummingbird VTVL and catching it on the launch mount, inspired by (back in 1980) seeing a skydiver land, throw off his gear, and catch another jumper whose leg had only just recently recovered from a break.

Re: reentry plasma vs methane- air combustion at 50:00, the pressure is so low during reentry, and the mixing of bleed gas and plasma so poor, that combustion would be incomplete before the velocity of the plasma would sweep the mixture away. In rocket terms, the energy release efficiency will be low.

For perspective, consider how the plume of Falcon 9 stops afterburning during the later part of ascent, going from flame to smoke. The mach 5-6 airflow can't sustain combustion even with the hot, rich exhaust from the Merlins because the density is too low.

Cody's Lab did some good demos of the fire tetrahedron, fuel-oxidizer-heat-reaction, where low pressure kills the reaction.

What an incredibly amazing opportunity! Elon has a reputation for being super busy, understandably, juggling multiple companies, each with their own industry leading projects all running at blistering paces.  To have him give you a personal unscripted tour, answering questions and getting such genuine, raw answers, over several hours, that is unheard of!  Just watching the videos feels so intimate and personal, I feel like not only are we getting a better understanding of Starbase and Starship, but of Elon as well. This wasn't a press release, or a meticulously planned tour like you would normally expect (or at least it didn't appear to be).  I have to imagine there was a corporate-type or a lawyer they had to either lock in a room, restrain, or otherwise subdue in order to get you this level of access.  Every time Elon reiterated the fact that his answers may not be correct, or they may be right for now, but things could change, there's a corporate lawyer on the verge of a heart attack.  You guys weren't even wearing safety helmets for crying out loud!  When he told you not to let anything fall on your head, an OSHA inspector developed a kidney stone!  I'm not going to say that you're lucky to have been offered such an opportunity, because I doubt he drew your name from a hat. You've been vlogging SpaceX progress at Starbase since the start, and you know rockets and space tech well enough to engage with him, asking intelligent questions, soliciting some eye-opening answers!  Great job! Thank you!  Looking forward to part 3!
Thank you so much for sharing this with us. ❤️

Elon mentioned that he would have no further use for any surviving Starship prototypes, but I was wondering if, with minor modifications, they could potentially later be converted into single-use fuel tankers, the advantage being that they could get more usable fuel to orbit since they wouldn't need to save any for re-entry, and could remove the heat-shield tiles and anything else needed for landing to increase the payload-to-orbit mass.

Other possible uses could include things like sending them on one-way trips to the moon or mars for potential future use as base infrastructure there. Since they're proven pressure vessels of a standardized design, they might be able to for example deliberately crash them on the end with the methane tanks, using those to absorb the impact of the crash and if the oxy tanks survive, poof, potentially habitable living space. They could become the Quonset huts of the moon or mars. You've also got steel rings manufactured to a specific set of dimensions that could potentially be recycled in other types of construction.

A question about distribution of mass between booster and ship. As we have seen so far, the booster is skirt-less (raptors are exposed), while starship has a skirt. What is the purpose of the skirt? My guess is structural support and protecting the raptors on descent. But for protection you would only need the front halt of the skirt (the one with the heat tiles). So my question is,  would it be a good idea if spacex cut the skirt in half and putting half of it on the ship and half of it on the booster? By doing so, my reasoning says that they would be able to carry more cargo since the dry mass of starship would decrease and the mass of the booster would increase. And because Tim has said in earlier videos that more dry mass on later stages of the rocket,  leads to a higher cargo mass penalty than on earlier stages of the rocket.

Elon was struggling at the end to explain how larger things appear to move slower because the internal shear forces from changes in moment of inertia and the centrifugal forces (plural - different components experience different accelerations) are vastly larger.  And there's the external aerodynamic forces which are orders of magnitude higher.  One way to express it is that as things scale up, rotation time must scale down.  A housefly can turn 180 degrees in 0.1s, but a 747 must take close to 3 minutes or it will break into many pieces.  The 747's speed at the outside of that arc is vastly higher than the housefly.  Saying it's slower is wrong, but trying to explain that in a few eloquent words, when perceptually it looks slow... he's not doing this interview to look stupid while he's being candid and correct lol.

Great video. Thanks Tim, and thanks Elon. I kind of got the feeling that Elon was just a tad nervous about what questions Tim might ask.  Did you notice Elon become a little concerned about showing too much of the rocket engines, but then said that he now had newer and better ones, and then casually continued on. I bet there are some things he wouldn't show Tim or talk to him about. Elon knows that millions of viewers will watch these videos. Some viewers are pessimistic and skeptical to the point where they will criticize even when success has already been proven, so he likely wants to be careful in his dialogue and humor. Tim was also asking a lot of questions, and many of them very technical and tough. Obviously Elon wanted to answer the questions as accurately as he could. All of these things could make the interview a little stressful after awhile. Escape systems hum, other than a few with parachutes I'm not aware of any escape systems on airplanes. They are built to take off and land every time. They are not 100% effective on either end but their modes of failure are well known and well within acceptable levels of risk. I think that's where the starship is headed. It's just going to have to have its failures come far enough into the program that people feel safe even after some people have died. No one remembers how many people died in the early days of flight. Yet thousands of people fly every day without much thought or fear of dying. People do still die but the risk of failure is so small and so many people have flown successively that few people can say they have never flown, or at the very least they know someone close to them that has flown. I envy the children of today that will feel this same way about space travel as their grandparents feel about flying.

I loved this. Probably historic. Thanks for creating this. But note to interviewer: you don't have to talk all the time, you don't have to fill silences. Let Elon talk. you're actually stepping on Elon's tour and his spontaneous thoughts. Many good questions--you're extremely well informed--but we're not that interested in your verbalizing, but rather what Elon has to say. Jumping to identify this or that element to show much you know often prevents us from hearing whatever Elon was going to say about it. Besides a polite, slightly irritated "yeah" in response. Please don't stop doing these, you have great access and they are tremendously valuable, but maybe study up on effective interview techniques.

Elon's comments on the Starship TPS were spot on.  The thermal expansion of components and the dynamics of that thermal wave are key thoughts.  The use of gap fillers (yea or nay) and SIP were other design elements on STS/Orbiter.  The goal of non-ablative is important because of the priority on reusability.  If you have to manually inspect and evaluate each part, TPS can become time consuming.  Penetration points (placement and shielding) become mission critical considerations.

I love this. At about 12 minutes Elon seems to have lost interest, maybe he's just feeling tired, but at 16 he's been asked an interesting question. "If on re-entry it all goes wrong and it's thousands of pieces on the bottom of the ocean, how will you know? Musk is immediately sucked into all the complexities, did he say "we'll have to have thermal cameras inside the tanks." ?? Is that a new idea on the spot? Then he loops around to an obvious solution and laughs.
at 18:00 'Stage zero' These are not individual rockets, these are individual components of the system. " Stage Zero is harder to make than the individual boosters." So the 'machine that fuels, and launches the machine...."
When Tesla announced that it was making its patents public - to encourage other manufacturers to make EVs, as an investor I was a bit annoyed. (Picture a frantic General Buck Turgidson in Dr Strangelove, hearing that the president invited the Soviet Ambassador to the War Room. "No offense, sir, but are you aware of what a serious breach of security that would be?! I mean, he'll see everything! He'll see the big board! " ) Now it's a few years later and it's increasingly clear: Tesla and Space X are making progress at such a rapid (and accelerating pace) that it really doesn't matter. It would be like LeBron James explaining his best trick - even to the rest of the NBA it might not matter that they know it, they're in no position to use it.
So 49 - 50 minutes. Cooling the hinge by pouring on methane and oxygen. "Even if it burns, it's already detached." YouTube science channels: How much can you cool down a red hot surface by blowing some combination of oxy methane (acetylene ?) on to it even though it all ignites and burns? (You should get, from a distance, a much bigger fireball, but where the gases are ejected the temperature should drop) Then again how hot does the tip of an oxy-acetylene torch get?
If this all is just a simulation than Elon Musk is simply the avatar being used to accelerate technological progress, which means he's no more important or essential than anyone else. I have a pretty big ego, but I don't think I'm a blip of any significance. So I think 'an' Elon Musk strongly indicates this is not a simulation, and he should get more sleep.

Ok, so a few questions. With Elon talking about margins in terms of thrust to weight, residual fuels and the like how large the margins are he is working from? For instance if he is working just on the ship/booster and such is he wanting massive margins when you have to take into account all the "upcoming" internals in terms of piloting the ship for people and the actual cabins and radiation area and mess etc. Does he have any conception yet of the masses involved of all those internals? Concerning the booster, with the grid fins always being out due to their not being a folding mechanism to save on weight and fault count. If I have it right the center and 8 around all gimbal to provide directional capabilities in the ascent. Given that the "Dino-traps" have enough control authority to help guide the booster down does it not follow that they have enough for the upwards journey too? So you could maybe get rid of all the gimballing engines or maybe just have the single center one gimbal helping reduce the complexity and accordingly larger chance of something failing? Looking at them with the pointy bits facing down, I imagine for some aerodynamic considerations, given they can rotate they could provide the same benefit going the other way. When in future they are building the human varient of the ship will they build the ship and then put in all the interals or would they use the same processes that they use to build massive ships like aircraft carriers and such and build chunks with all the stuff already installed and then just put the bits togehter and weld. I mean will they make each ring section and have everything there that would be when assembled? If I remember from something I have seen previously Elon may have mentioned that the TPS system would only be needed for lunar or other planetary re-entries due to the massive increase of speed but the steel on its own could handle orbital speeds re-entry without losing integrity. Given how starship is so much more than a dumb rocket as it is coming back in from the moon or Mars etc could it not do a flip and burn to shed enough speed before re-entry, getting back into landing orientation after this, to negate the need for the TPS system altogether or will the TPS also provide some benefit when in transit ie thermal/radiation protection etc? Thank you for any answers that can be provided :~)

Elon is a genius, but you have to remember that his asperger's (on the autism spectrum) makes it hard for him to swap trains of thought; he has to think things through to a point where he is happy before swapping to something else. That's why in the interview there were a few points where he was obviously thinking about something, and completely blanked a different question, then asked for the question to be repeated after he finished his previous train of thought - he wasn't being rude, and it wasnt that he wasn't able to hear, it was just that he was just focussed on something else and "needed" to finish that first. This kind of thinking is VERY useful in problem solving - 100% focus on a problem without distraction - but can appear socially different during conversations. Given a choice, I would take his way of thinking over "normal" anyday. Remember: some of the greatest minds of all time had "learning differences", like Albert Einstein was very dyslexic, but was MUCH better at solving problems than "normal learners". That's why they are called "learning differences" rather than "learning difficulties", because these minds are often much stronger in areas that others are weaker in.

Every company could be this amazing, but when they replace the original idea, brains and passion with people with "degrees" that leads to all to familiar humdrum corporate structures equaling even less impressive end products both in quality and achievements. America was built by the top brass having hands just as dirty as any other worker (if not more!), and we need that to return desperately, and this is a modern example of that in action.

Mechanical tile attachment is a maintenance leap over shuttle, which had a complex bonding system which required complex removal and prep for replacement tiles.  I see guys hand pounding them on here.  Otherwise seems much the same, though tiles may be mechanically tougher to impacts over silica,  thus longer lasting overall.   Sounds heavy though weight doesn’t seem to be much of a consideration at this point in development.  Proof of many concurrent novel concepts is immediate goal.  And as a former weights and mass properties engineer, I love that he really doesn’t know the weights/inertias of his flight stack and has enough thrust margin to not make it a critical preflight issue (it’s the supertanker of rockets though will take off amazingly fast). It’s good see a man striding the earth making his dreams real and being self-aware enough to wonder if he is in a video game.

Superb interviewing Tim.  Thank you! Regarding Elon's willingness to do another interview in several months.  Having spent 18 years as an engineering infrastructure manager at high tech companies in Silicon Valley, I'd be really interested if you were able to query Elon about how he (and other leaders) engages with SpaceX's process.  In other words, there are "emergency" or "immediate" interventions/involvements that are required, and then there are "contextual" involvements where the team and its managers monitor the organization's processes and make sure that the ethos/philosophy/engineering processes of the organization are operating as they should.  Another way to think of this is "what are the organization's guardrails" and how do they operate?   Elon touched upon the learnings of such a process in the first episode of the interview when he discussed examples of getting it wrong.  Like the challenge of "building the factory", building the ethos and mindset of SpaceX's team and monitoring for divergence from those processes strike me as core aspects of SpaceX's success.  I'd really like to understand why they are so successful at these.

It is probably the case that watching, studying, and analyzing these interviews is essential "reading" for every engineer, manager, and builder in the world-wide space industry.  This interview spells out the 'why?' of SpaceX's success thus far.  (Of course the SpaceX philosophy applies to the solution of any engineering challenge.)  If I found anything 'disingenuous'  (probably not the right word)  in what Elon said in this 2nd part, it was his explanation for the 'why?' that SpaceX is being so public about their process and progress.  Yes it is hard to "hide" the tower arms when Starbase is located on a public road, but SpaceX CHOSE to put Starbase on a public road.  And Elon has chosen to provide an in-depth tour and interview.  Why?  I submit that  SpaceX NEEDS the support of 'everyman' as it undertakes making humanity multi-planetary.  It NEEDS popular support to push the FAA to be more responsive, and to ensure that NASA is supported in its support of SpaceX.  And inside its own organization, SpaceX NEEDS to drive home the importance of SpaceX's core design, build, iterate, don't be afraid to fail philosophy.  What better way than to have it's founder and CEO demonstrate that ethos in the most public way possible.
Paying £1 to see this early is the best money I've ever spent.
